title: 1096-C
statement: C. Polygon for the Angletime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an angle $$$\\text{ang}$$$.The Jury asks You to find suchregular$$$n$$$-gon (regular polygon with $$$n$$$ vertices) that it has three vertices $$$a$$$, $$$b$$$ and $$$c$$$ (they can be non-consecutive) with $$$\\angle{abc} = \\text{ang}$$$ or report that there is no such $$$n$$$-gon.If there are several answers, print theminimalone. It is guarantied that if answer exists then it doesn't exceed $$$998244353$$$.InputThe first line contains single integer $$$T$$$ ($$$1 \\le T \\le 180$$$) — the number of queries.Each of the next $$$T$$$ lines contains one integer $$$\\text{ang}$$$ ($$$1 \\le \\text{ang} < 180$$$) — the angle measuredin degrees.OutputFor each query print single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$3 \\le n \\le 998244353$$$) — minimal possible number of vertices in the regular $$$n$$$-gon or $$$-1$$$ if there is no such $$$n$$$.ExampleInput4 54 50 2 178Output10 18 90 180NoteThe answer for the first query is on the picture above.The answer for the second query is reached on a regular $$$18$$$-gon. For example, $$$\\angle{v_2 v_1 v_6} = 50^{\\circ}$$$.The example angle for the third query is $$$\\angle{v_{11} v_{10} v_{12}} = 2^{\\circ}$$$.In the fourth query, minimal possible $$$n$$$ is $$$180$$$ (not $$$90$$$).

processed.result:
You are given an angle  $\text{ang}$.  Find the smallest number of vertices, $n$,  a regular polygon can have so that three of its vertices, $a$, $b$, and $c$, form an angle of $\text{ang}$ degrees. If no such polygon exists, output -1. 

The input consists of multiple test cases. Each test case contains a single integer $\text{ang}$ (1 ≤ $\text{ang}$ < 180) representing the angle.

Output the smallest possible value of $n$ for each test case, or -1 if no such polygon exists.
Given an angle, find the smallest number of sides a regular polygon can have so that three of its vertices form that angle. If no such polygon exists, output -1.
